content:
A good article on UI backwards compatibility, on a popular blog I follow:
https://danluu.com/ui-compatibility/
(notable that Zulip is the first example!)
@Tim Abbott @Steve Howell @Rishi Gupta @Brock Whittaker will be interested to read it ^^^

Around the time they made that change, they made another change such that a series of clicks that would cause you to send a private message to someone would instead cause you to send a private message to the alphabetically first person who was online.

Does anyone know what this alludes to?
And as for ctrl-enter, at least currently ctrl-enter seems to work find for entering a new line without sending?
My takeaway from this is that we should make all our breaking hotkey changes soon, since we're still at a tiny fraction of the users we hope to have even a couple of months from now :).
I think the ctrl+enter problem was fixed soon after, due to (probably the author) reporting it on chat.zulip.org.

I agree with @Rishi Gupta. We're still very early in our growth, so in a few months, 90% of our users will only have war stories going back to 1.8. Also, most people only keep a couple hotkeys in muscle memory, so the odds of even current users having mental attachments to the "C" key (or is it the "c" key?) is low. Just don't hit the ESC key is my advice. :wink:
I'm pinging the author to find out what he's alluding to with his second comment.
(For context, Dan is part of the Recurse Center community)
Haha that explains war stories going back to pre-message-edit days. :grinning:

Dan's blog is awesome. I'd love for all software engineers to read this post:
https://danluu.com/everything-is-broken/

If you like people who rant on software...

https://twitter.com/garybernhardt

Gary's rants are entertaining (and his live-typing in presentations is a wonder to behold), but I don't feel like I learned that much afterward.

Dan's posts feel like they have much more to chew on. I'm actually a little bit surprised to see the word "rant" come up in connection with them, because I don't file them in that mental bucket at all, though I can see why now that you mention it.
I don’t mean “rant” in a bad way.
